conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions Committee, I’m Student_D. School_D is my first-choice school because I’m especially interested in your academic environment and would be excited to contribute positively to the community. I would like to formally apply and be considered for your available seat.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, and there is no downside to applying immediately because each school has capacity 1 and priorities are identical across schools. Applying early to my first choice maximizes my chance to secure it before capacity is filled.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. After reviewing this round’s decisions, we are not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest in School_D and wish you the best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_D applied in round 1 and is my 4th choice on my true priority list (A > B > C > D > E). With quota 1, accepting now would lock in a lower-priority match and foreclose the possibility of matching with Student_A/B/C if they later apply. Given full information: Student_A ranks School_D 4th, Student_B ranks School_D 5th, Student_C ranks School_D 4th, Student_E ranks School_D 5th—so higher-priority students are unlikely to target me early, but they could become unmatched later and apply. Still, immediate acceptance is not required; I can reject now to preserve the seat for higher-priority candidates. There is no mechanism to hold/waitlist; only accept or reject on APPLY. Therefore, reject to keep option value for A/B/C.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_C and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m applying because your program is the best fit for my goals, and I would accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_C is my top true choice. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I am behind Student_A and Student_B everywhere. To maximize my chance at my top option, I should apply immediately to School_C rather than risk losing it if higher-priority students also apply later. Even if rejected, I can pivot to School_B next round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C.

Please confirm your acceptance per the process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and only Student_C has applied this round. My true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C, but there is no guarantee they will apply to us (Student_A ranks us 3rd; Student_B ranks us 2nd). Student_C ranks us 1st and is applying now, so accepting secures a filled seat with an acceptable candidate on our list. Given no competing higher-priority applicants in the inbox and the risk of ending unmatched, accept Student_C.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_B and I’m formally applying. School_A is my first choice because I’m looking for a rigorous academic environment and I’m eager to contribute actively to classes and school activities. If admitted, I would commit and enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_A. All schools share the same priority order with Student_A ranked above me, so School_A is likely competitive. Still, the best strategy to maximize my outcome is to apply immediately to my top choice and make a clear, committed case for fit and enthusiasm rather than delay.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_A. Please confirm your intent to enroll and we’ll share next steps for enrollment and orientation.
conversation.thought: My true priority ranks Student_A above Student_B. However, in this round my only applicant is Student_B, who also ranks me as their first choice, making acceptance immediately secure. If I reject to wait for Student_A, I risk losing my seat if Student_A never applies (they prefer School_B first) or matches elsewhere. With quota 1 and no better candidate currently available, accepting Student_B maximizes expected outcome while ensuring a match now.

conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school. I’m applying because your program and environment are the best fit for my goals, and I would be committed to enrolling if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply to my top choice (School_E) immediately. All schools share the same priority order where I (Student_E) am last, so I have little leverage later. Securing my first choice early is my best chance before other students fill remaining slots elsewhere.

conversation.message: Thank you for your application, Student_E. We appreciate that School_E is your first choice and your commitment to enroll if admitted. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. Welcome!
conversation.thought: Student_E is applying now and is within our true priority list, but they are last on it. Since we have full information, higher-priority students (A–D) all rank School_E last, so they are very unlikely to apply here unless rejected everywhere else. Waiting risks ending up unfilled, while accepting Student_E secures a match with a committed first-choice applicant within quota 1. Therefore accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first-choice school, and I’m excited about the opportunity to join your community. I’m ready to commit if admitted and would be honored to take the available seat. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_B. I have highest priority at every school, so a direct application should secure acceptance if School_B follows its priority list. No need to waste a round with TALK.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_B is your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission and would be excited to welcome you to School_B. Congratulations—your seat is confirmed with this acceptance.
conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_B's true priority list and has applied in round 1 stating School_B is their first choice and they are ready to commit. With quota 1, accepting now secures our top-ranked student and there is no benefit to waiting for a higher-priority candidate (none exist).

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions Committee, thank you for considering me last round. I’m reapplying for the currently available seat because School_D remains my clear first choice. If admitted, I will accept immediately and fully commit to enrolling. I believe I would contribute positively to the School_D community through consistent effort and engagement in academics and school life. Thank you again for your consideration.
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Although I was rejected in round 1 (likely due to higher-priority applicants taking the seat), School_D now appears available again, so I should re-apply with a concise, stronger commitment and signal that I will accept immediately if offered.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your continued interest and for reapplying. After reviewing our options for this round, we are not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your strong commitment to School_D and encourage you to continue pursuing the best available options in the market.
conversation.thought: Student_D is applying again and is highly interested in us (we are their first choice), which reduces the risk of losing them if we accept. However, our true priority list ranks Student_D 4th (behind A, B, C). Since we have quota 1 and no current matches, it is strategically better to keep the seat available in hopes that a higher-priority student (A/B/C) may apply in later rounds. Our priorities are identical across schools, so top students may be competed over, but holding for at least a bit longer can improve our outcome. Therefore, reject Student_D again this round.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions Committee, thank you again for considering me in prior rounds. I’m applying once more because School_D remains my first choice, and if admitted I will immediately and fully commit to enrolling. I understand you may be weighing fit for the remaining seat; I can offer reliability and strong day-to-day contribution (consistent academic effort, respectful collaboration with peers, and active participation in school activities). If there is any particular quality or role you are prioritizing for this last seat, I would be grateful to be considered in that light. Thank you for your time and consideration.
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Although I was rejected twice, School_D still has an open seat, so the best strategy is to apply again with a clearer value proposition and credible commitment, while politely asking if there is any specific profile/need I can match to help them finalize their remaining seat.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your continued interest and for the thoughtful update. At this time, we are not able to offer you admission for the available seat. We recognize your strong commitment to School_D and encourage you to continue pursuing other options in the market as well. [REJECT]
conversation.thought: School_D has quota 1 and true priority list ranks Student_D 4th (behind A, B, C). Student_D strongly prefers School_D first and is repeatedly applying, but accepting now could block a higher-priority student (A/B/C) who may approach later. Given we can only respond to applicants and currently only Student_D is in inbox, the optimal strategy to maximize match on true priority is to hold the seat for higher-ranked candidates while rounds remain. Therefore reject again this round.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions Committee,

I’m applying again for the remaining seat because School_D is still my clear first choice. If offered admission, I will accept immediately and withdraw from all other options.

If you are deciding among candidates for a specific need (academic focus, club leadership, community service, etc.), I would be grateful to be considered for that role—I’m ready to contribute reliably and consistently to the School_D community from day one.

Thank you for your continued consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_D
conversation.thought: Only School_D remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. Although I have been rejected in prior rounds, continuing to apply is still optimal because any eventual acceptance at School_D dominates all other outcomes for me, and I cannot target any other school this round. I will submit a concise final-commitment application and ask if there is any specific need I can address for the last seat.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your continued commitment to School_D and for your clear intent to enroll immediately if admitted. We are pleased to offer you admission for our available seat. Please confirm your acceptance and withdrawal from other options as stated. Welcome to School_D. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D is ranked 4th on our true priority list (A, B, C, D, E). However, in this round our only applicant is Student_D, and we have quota 1 with no current match. Waiting for a higher-priority student is risky because Student_A ranks School_D 4th, Student_B ranks School_D last, Student_C ranks School_D 4th, and Student_E ranks School_D last; none are likely to apply soon. Student_D ranks us 1st and will commit immediately, securing our seat now rather than potentially ending unmatched after round 30. Given the market incentives and repeated demonstrated commitment, accepting Student_D is optimal versus holding out for unlikely higher-ranked applicants.
